New Records: Freddie Freeman hit the first walk-off grand slam in World Series history to win Game 1.
Freddie Freeman became the seventh Dodger to homer in consecutive World Series games, and the first since Justin Turner in 2020.
This year’s Dodgers are just the eighth team with consecutive games in the same World Series with five or more extra-base hits, and the first since Houston in 2017.
Key Match Events: Freddie Freeman hit a walk-off grand slam in Game 1 and tripled earlier in the game.
The Dodgers had five extra-base hits in each of the first two games against the Yankees.
Jack Flaherty allowed just two runs in his 5⅓ innings in Game 1.
Yoshinobu Yamamoto allowed only a Juan Soto solo home run in his 6⅓ innings in Game 2.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers kept both games close thanks to very good starting pitching.
Aaron Judge has struggled so far with six strikeouts and just one single in two games.
The Yankees' big three (Soto, Stanton, and Judge) are a combined 6-for-25 with two home runs and two walks so far.
The Dodgers' big three (Freeman, Ohtani, and Betts) are a combined 6-for-24 with two home runs, a triple, double, and two walks.
